items.title: Google requires API Key
items.body: Does your code supports Google's reverse geocoding since they require the use of an API key? I quickly browsed through your documentation but couldn't find anything on how to use Google API key. Please advise.

items.title: no module named 'geocoder'
items.body:
I installed geocoder by using `git clone https://github.com/DenisCarriere/geocoder`
Now I have a Python3 file where I `import geocoder`. 
But when I run my .py file, I get "no module named 'geocoder'. 
Does anyone know what I am doing wrong? Or maybe only Python2 is supported and not Python3?
Just starting with Python on my Raspberry Pi, help would be appreciated!

items.title: freegeoip __deprecation_message__; deadline July 1st, 2018
items.body:
From a command like

> geocode --provider freegeoip 138.197.111.108

the output includes the key/value pair:

`"__deprecation_message__": "This API endpoint is deprecated and will stop working on July 1st, 2018. For more information please visit: https://github.com/apilayer/freegeoip#readme"`

In addition to API changes, [the new readme](https://github.com/apilayer/freegeoip#readme) says free accounts will be able to access up to 10,000 requests per month, not per hour.

items.title: OpenCage API: add language parameter
items.body:
With the optional parameter language results in that language are favored:
https://geocoder.opencagedata.com/api#forward-opt

It would be nice if the parameter language was accepted:
`geocoder.opencage([45.15, -75.14], method='reverse', language='de', key=<API_KEY>)
`

items.title: Default "fuzzy" parameter value for Geonames
items.body:
In Geocoder's wrapper for Geonames "fuzzy" is 0.8 by default. 
https://github.com/DenisCarriere/geocoder/blob/16a697240974b2cb66df56b534be43ef26218110/geocoder/geonames.py#L93

Is there some reasoning behind this value?

The Geonames' docs say:
http://www.geonames.org/export/geonames-search.html

>default is '1', defines the fuzziness of the search terms. float between 0 and 1. The search term is only applied to the name attribute.

Perhaps it is better to use the defaults suggested by the service documentation?

* * *

I probably wouldn't raise this issue if Geonames' idea of fuzziness wasn't about messing up search result relevance. For example, if I search for "Russia" with Geocoder's current defaults:

```
g = geocoder.geonames('Russia', key='KEY')
g.geojson
```

I will get a region in Jamaica called "Russia". However, as a user I would prefer to see countries first and regions second, but "fuzzy" interferes with result relevance. This behavior is easy to replicate without Geocoder by manually altering search query in the URL:

http://www.geonames.org/search.html?q=russia&country=&fuzzy=0.8

This is definitely not the package maintainers' fault, but since Geonames service doesn't do fuzziness right, perhaps it's a good idea to set fuzzy to 1.0, as their docs suggest?

items.title: geonames premium server
items.body: After purchasing credits from geonames, we are required to use the premium server "ws.geonames.net". There is no straightforward way to change the url within the package.

items.title: Regression on #248, ability to add custom params and headers
items.body:
The logic for `self.params` and `self.headers` is broken... The custom params (in `kwargs`) should be _combined_ with the result of `self._build_params()` but now they are being preferred to the built-in params of the provider, resulting in access forbidden errors, for example (the API key is not sent in the request if a custom param is provided). The same goes for the headers.

The exact locations are: https://github.com/DenisCarriere/geocoder/blob/535feea845fa52ad392d958bdfa95d06c688ddc5/geocoder/base.py#L392-L393 and https://github.com/DenisCarriere/geocoder/blob/535feea845fa52ad392d958bdfa95d06c688ddc5/geocoder/base.py#L388-L389

items.title: Opencage reverse geocoding issue
items.body:
Hi, 

This one had me stumped for quite a while as I had no idea where the problem lay, however I think I have gotten to the bottom of it. There is an error in the _build_params of OpenCageReverse:

The 'query' is using self.location when it should be just location:
 ```
def _build_params(self, location, provider_key, **kwargs):
        location = Location(location)
        return {
            'query': self.location,
            'key': provider_key,
        }
```
The first way causes the request to turn out like this:
https://api.opencagedata.com/geocode/v1/json?query=52.882079&query=11.747445&key=xxx

which returns garbage... I was wondering why my requests were coming back with really odd locations...

 ```
def _build_params(self, location, provider_key, **kwargs):
        location = Location(location)
        return {
            'query': location,
            'key': provider_key,
        }
```

With this, the request looks much better... : 
http://api.opencagedata.com/geocode/v1/json?query=49.973888%2C+8.069823&key=xxx

Not sure if this is the actual root cause, as I haven't followed everything all the way back, but it seems to resolve it for now

items.title: geocoder.google vs others?
items.body:
When I am running `geocoder.google('11 Wall Street, New York')` I receive `<[OK] Google - Geocode [11 Wall St, New York, NY 10005, USA]>`

However, when I am running `geocoder.osm('11 Wall Street, New York')` or `geocoder.yandex('11 Wall Street, New York')` I get `Status code Unknown from https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/search: ERROR - HTTPSConnectionPool(host='nominatim.openstreetmap.org', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /search?q=175+5th+Avenue+NYC&format=jsonv2&addressdetails=1&limit=1 (Caused by ProxyError('Cannot connect to proxy.', OSError('Tunnel connection failed: 407 Proxy Authentication Required ( Forefront TMG requires authorization to fulfill the request. Access to the Web Proxy filter is denied.  )',)))`

How come there is a different treatment of google vs everything else? How can I get osm working as well?

items.title: Improve Open Street Map OSM
items.body:
Hello,

the open street map nomination api provides more detailed querys: http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Nominatim

As I understand the project to support this we need a class like that one:
`class OsmQueryDetail(MultipleResultsQuery):
    """
    Nominatim
    =========
    Nominatim (from the Latin, 'by name') is a tool to search OSM data by name
    and address and to generate synthetic addresses of OSM points (reverse geocoding).

    API Reference
    -------------
    http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Nominatim
    """
    provider = 'osm'
    method = 'geocode'

    _URL = 'https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/search'
    _RESULT_CLASS = OsmResult
    _KEY_MANDATORY = False

    def _build_params(self, location, provider_key, **kwargs):
        # backward compatitibility for 'limit' (now maxRows)
        if 'limit' in kwargs:
            logging.warning(
                "argument 'limit' in OSM is deprecated and should be replaced with maxRows")
            kwargs['maxRows'] = kwargs['limit']
        # build params
        query = {
            'format': 'jsonv2',
            'addressdetails': 1,
            'limit': kwargs.get('maxRows', 1),
        }
        query.update(kwargs)
        return query

    def _before_initialize(self, location, **kwargs):
        """ Check if specific URL has not been provided, otherwise, use cls._URL"""
        url = kwargs.get('url', '')
        if url.lower() == 'localhost':
            self.url = 'http://localhost/nominatim/search'
        elif url:
            self.url = url
        # else:  do not change self.url, which is cls._URL`

And adding        
    'osm': {
        'geocode': OsmQuery,
        'detail': OsmQueryDetail,
        'reverse': OsmReverse,
    }

That works fine for me. That is my query that is working now:
geocoder.osm("",postalcode="45326", street="Ellernstrasse", method="detail")

I wanted to make a pull request but it didn't worked. Don't have the rights I guess.

items.title: KeyError on call to geocoder.google
items.body:
Hello,

I'm getting a KeyError when looking up a specific string with the Google geocoder backend:

```
>>> geocoder.google("Cerro Torre Mountain")
Requested https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/geocode/json?address=Cerro+Torre+Mountain&bounds=&components=&region=&language=

(lots of traceback)

~/src/earth/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/geocoder/base.py in _parse_json_with_fieldnames(self)
    117             if not key.startswith('_') and key not in self._TO_EXCLUDE:
    118                 self.fieldnames.append(key)
--> 119                 value = getattr(self, key)
    120                 if value:
    121                     self.json[key] = value

~/src/earth/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/geocoder/google.py in country(self)
    132     @property
    133     def country(self):
--> 134         return self.raw['country'].get('short_name')
    135 
    136     @property

KeyError: 'country'
```

This doesn't seem to happen with the other place names I've tried, and the JSON response I get looks valid. Is this expected?

Sorry if I've missed something in the docs and this is not a bug!

items.title: Opencage lookup broken
items.body:
Hi, 

The Opencage lookup seems to be broken again. I get the following error:

```
 File "..\lib\site-packages\geocoder\base.py", line 120, in _parse_json_with_fieldnames
    value = getattr(self, key)
  File "..\lib\site-packages\geocoder\opencage.py", line 359, in bbox
    south = self.raw['bounds']['southwest'].get('lat')
```

I can solve it by putting a try, except around the bit:

```
            try:
                value = getattr(self, key)
                if value:
                    self.json[key] = value
            except Exception as e:
                print(e)
```

but I'm not sure that that is the best solution... :)

I'm not sure how the new multiple search results have changed things and if it will be a general error, or only an error with opencage.

items.title: Accuracy is always None in 1.29.1 with Google Geocode
items.body:
Once upgrading to 1.29.1, the google geocode accuracy value is always None.

In 1.25:
```
>>> import geocoder
>>> r = geocoder.google("326 Chestnut Hill Rd New Boston, NH 03070", key='XYZ')
>>> r.accuracy
u'ROOFTOP'
```

In 1.29.1:
```
>>> import geocoder
>>> r = geocoder.google("326 Chestnut Hill Rd New Boston, NH 03070", key='XYZ')
>>> r.accuracy
>>> r.accuracy is None
True
```

I would expect the accuracy to return the same in both versions. Unless this was removed? I couldn't find anything in the documentation about this functionality being removed.

items.title: Orderedset can't be installed without C++?
items.body:
@ebreton Strange, can't install `geocoder` anymore on Windows.

The root of the problem seems to be coming from `orderedset`.

## Solution

Isn't a native Python way to do this or can we simply include the Python code directly instead of relying on an external unstable dependency.

Bundle this internally?
https://github.com/LuminosoInsight/ordered-set/blob/master/ordered_set.py

## Logs

```
(env) C:\Users\Owner\Documents\GitHub>pip install geocoder
Collecting geocoder
  Using cached geocoder-1.25.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Collecting six (from geocoder)
  Using cached six-1.10.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl

items.title: lang_code in OSM reverse
items.body:
Hi, lang_code(OSM reverse) is't described in manual
tnx

items.title: updating what3words provider to use API v2
items.body:
Hi,

I can see the what3words provider is using what3words API v1. 

what do you think about updating to use what3words API v2 ?

here is a commit with the changes https://github.com/tsamaya/geocoder/commit/c14acde44eeab659cd08dbf96befbe8b87252eb5

I added a unit test for what3words and left it commented as I don't know if it will break travis build.

Please let me know what do you think and I can make a PR

items.title: "ImportError: No module named orderedset" in release 1.24.0
items.body:
The latest release makes use of the package `orderedset` without putting it as a required dependency in `setup.py` and therefore breaks installs.

Possibly travis builds should not install via `requirements.txt` but via `pip install -e .` in order to catch these mistakes.

items.title: Opencage 'street' not picking up all aliases
geocoder.ip('me').country returns None
items.body:
Thanks for a great package that's worked in my system, [Mycodo](https://github.com/kizniche/Mycodo), for over a year without an issue.

Recently (past week or so), I've been having the country query return None, from systems around the world.

```python
import geocoder
print("Country='{return}'".format(return=geocoder.ip('me').country))
```

```bash
$ python ./test_geocoder.py
Country='None'
```

I haven't dug enough into geocoder to know exactly how to debug this.

Is this a known issue? Is there anything I can do to help?

items.title: Passing custom `params` and `headers` to the geocoder
items.body:
What I tried and wanted to acheive:
```python
geocoder.opencage('budapest', language='eo')
```
I get `<[OK] Opencage - Geocode [Budapest, Hungary]>` instead of  `<[OK] Opencage - Geocode [Budapeŝto, Hungarujo]>`

But this may be limited: if I’d like to pass other parameters, there is a lot of options for just Opencage.

I would like to be able to pass any `params` or `headers` just like the _requests_ API.

```python
geocoder.opencage('budapest', params={'language':'eo'})
```
or 
```python
geocoder.opencage('budapest', headers={'Accept-Language': 'eo'})
```

items.title: Documentation for error handling
items.body:
I tried searching for "error", "fail" and "status" using https://geocoder.readthedocs.io/search.html but did not find any useful results.

I want to know what happens when the location lookup fails, either because the network is down, authentication fails, a rate limit is exceeded, or because the address could not be found in the database.

Playing around shows that the geocoder result object has attributes `ok`, `confidence`, `quality` and so on, what do these mean? Do these have a defined meaning across all providers or are they provider-specific?

In short, how do I check for failed lookups and report them to the user?

items.title: Reverse geocoding for google provider doesn't work
items.body:
When running the example from the docs:

```python
import geocoder
g = geocoder.google([45.15, -75.14], method='reverse')
```

reverse geocoding does not complete and the geocoding object returns: `<[INVALID_REQUEST] Google - Reverse>`.
It seems that the url is malformed. I will try to submit a PR within the weekend.

Issue with 1.21 version:

```python
import geocoder
results = geocoder.google(
    location=[1.1, 1.1],
    method='reverse',
)
```

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)

      2     location=[1.1, 1.1],
----> 3     method='reverse',
      4 )

**/lib/python3.5/site-packages/geocoder/api.py in google(location, **kwargs)
    184         > elevation
    185     """
--> 186     return get(location, provider='google', **kwargs)
    187
    188

**/lib/python3.5/site-packages/geocoder/api.py in get(location, **kwargs)

--> 152     return options[provider][method](location, **kwargs)

**/lib/python3.5/site-packages/geocoder/google_reverse.py in __init__(self, location, **kwargs)
     35             'client': kwargs.get('client', google_client)

---> 37         if self.client and self.client_secret:

Thanks

items.title: Google Reverse Geocode Not Adding Signature When Using Client Id
items.body:
Im trying to use the google reverse geocoder with a client id and client secret. It used to work in the previous version but now its giving me issues. I have checked the generated request and i noticed that its missing the signature.

example:
geocoder.google([latitude, longitude], method='reverse', client='client', client_secret='client secret')

the generated request: https://maps.googleapis.com:443 "GET /maps/api/geocode/json?sensor=false&latlng=-29.81468939999%2C+30.860086100000004&client=client&language= HTTP/1.1"

If i use the googlemaps library the generated request will be: https://maps.googleapis.com:443 "GET /maps/api/geocode/json?latlng=-29.814689%2C30.860086&client=client&signature=signature HTTP/1.1"

items.title: Session persistance documentation missing?

It times out/is unstable on only a few thousand rows. I saw something about session persistance in the docs, but the documentation/example is missing:

https://geocoder.readthedocs.io/api.html#using-a-session


Thanks!

Hi,

When I use geocoder for Googleplex, it can find out the correct geocode.
But when I use it for 'Googleplex - QD3', the geocode is null.
Any advice for this?

Thanks

items.title: No documentation for using Sessions in forward-geocoding
items.body:
Hello,
    I was going through the documentation [geocoder.readthedocs.io](http://geocoder.readthedocs.io/api.html#using-a-session) and it mentions the usage of session along with geocoder. However, the actual information on how to use sessions is missing.

items.title: Yandex geocoder moved to https
items.body:
Each request to yandex geocoder now causing two real requests - first is just for redirect:

    >>> geocoder.yandex(location=['37.61892', '55.756994'], method='reverse')
    INFO 2017-02-05 03:15:33,314 [none] requests.packages.urllib3.connectionpool: Starting new HTTP connection (1): geocode-maps.yandex.ru
    DEBUG 2017-02-05 03:15:33,358 [none] requests.packages.urllib3.connectionpool: "GET /1.x/?lang=en-US&kind=&geocode=37.61892%2C+55.756994&results=1&format=json HTTP/1.1" 301 184
    INFO 2017-02-05 03:15:33,362 [none] requests.packages.urllib3.connectionpool: Starting new HTTPS connection (1): geocode-maps.yandex.ru
    DEBUG 2017-02-05 03:15:33,477 [none] requests.packages.urllib3.connectionpool: "GET /1.x/?lang=en-US&kind=&geocode=37.61892%2C+55.756994&results=1&format=json HTTP/1.1" 200 None

According to [API documentation](https://tech.yandex.com/maps/doc/geocoder/desc/concepts/input_params-docpage/) request should always be sent using https.

items.title: Use sessions from python-requests to fasten execution
items.body: As described here http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/user/advanced/#session-objects when we have a batch of requests to make, it is better to make use of a session object.

items.title: Unofficial endpoint for FreeGeoIP causes intermittent errors
items.body:
In c54c9ad6, the REST endpoint for FreeGeoIP was changed from the official one at http://freegeoip.net/ to https://telize.j3ss.co/geoip/. What was the rationale behind this?

The unofficial endpoint seems to respond inconsistently: sometimes latitude and longitude are strings, and sometimes either latitude or longitude are missing entirely, causing "ERROR - No Geometry" from Geocoder.

items.title: ArcGIS 10.3 SSL connection fail
items.body:
From email:

I've been working with your geocoder python module.  It's been fantastic so far - I've been able to pull from mapquest and bing with no issues.  I'm currently reverse geocoding a big file of addresses and trying to compare the results from multiple geocoders.  I've had success with some but a few such as google, mapbox and geocode farm seem to print this error/warning:

> C:\Python27\ArcGIS10.3\lib\site-packages\requests\packages\urllib3\util\ssl_.py:120: InsecurePlatformWarning: A true SSLContext object is not available. This prevents urllib3 from configuring SSL appropriately and may cause certain SSL connections to fail. For more information, see https://urllib3.readthedocs.org/en/latest/security.html#insecureplatformwarning.
  InsecurePlatformWarning

I'm not a programmer by trade and mostly work with GIS processes so the cause for this eludes me.   I was wondering if you were familiar with this issue at all.  I'd appreciate any feedback.

I then added it as a parameter to the script itself and still the same issue.  

Not sure what I'm doing wrong but any help would be great!

Thanks!

Ryan

Just found this project and really like the idea. I use quite heavily [PCA Predict's](http://www.pcapredict.com/en-gb/geocoding-service/) API in one of my projects, due to an agreement we have with them. Suggest to add this provider.

I'm happy to check it out when time permits, but first wanted to ask if that's OK?

items.title: Tomtom Geocode is broken

Tomtom changed their documentation. The base url is not longer: https://api.tomtom.com/lbs/geocoding/geocode  but instead: https://api.tomtom.com/search/2/geocode/

Then. If I try to use the tomtom provider, it results in a broken api call.

TomTom's documentation: http://developer.tomtom.com/products/onlinenavigation/onlinesearch/documentation/Geocoding/Geocode

items.title: How to get region border coordinates (polyline) data?
items.body:
I'm trying to get (specified) region borders as GMaps coordinates (to form a polyline) from Google Maps. Is this possible in some way? (either from maps.google.com).
**NOTE**
 I know you can draw/outline regions manually with tools intended for it (like http://www.birdtheme.org/useful/v3tool.html), but covering a large region ACCURATELY is a ton of work. The draw-it-yourself answer is not an option in this case.

**Example**
1. https://maps.google.com/ -> type in "Ottawa, Canada"
2. You can see the pink-ish border that outlines the wanted region
3. That border is the polyline that I need the coordinates of

**Requirements:**
- Extract the region data coordinates (if available) from a given search (as in the example)
- If the previous is not possible, a source to an ACCURATE map boundaries of the region is required

items.title: US Census Geocoder addition
items.body:

I have just started doing geocoding in Python, primarily trying to use

http://www.census.gov/geo/maps-data/data/geocoder.html

for batch geocoding but haven't been able to retrieve any data.

Any possibility of you adding this one to your set of geocoders?

I think that all the other US geocoders eventually rely on maps, etc from
the Census such as the TIGER maps so it would be a great primary source!

items.body:
Email by: Roy Thorsby

I'm currently reverse geocoding a big file of addresses and trying to compare the results from multiple geocoders.  I've had success with some but a few such as google, mapbox and geocode farm seem to print this error/warning:

```
C:\Python27\ArcGIS10.3\lib\site-packages\requests\packages\urllib3\util\ssl_.py:120: InsecurePlatformWarning: A true SSLContext object is not available. This prevents urllib3 from configuring SSL appropriately and may cause certain SSL connections to fail. For more information, see https://urllib3.readthedocs.org/en/latest/security.html#insecureplatformwarning.
  InsecurePlatformWarning
```

I'm not a programmer by trade and mostly work with GIS processes so the cause for this eludes me.   I was wondering if you were familiar with this issue at all.  I'd appreciate any feedback.

items.title: Question: changelog
items.body:
Hi !
Great lib !

Is there any changelog for it ?

items.title: Recent commit has broken geocodefarm.py
items.body:
Relevant part of my stack trace:

```
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/geocoder/__init__.py", line 36, in <module>
    from geocoder.api import get, yahoo, bing, geonames, mapquest, google, mapbox  # noqa
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/geocoder/api.py", line 31, in <module>
    from geocoder.geocodefarm import GeocodeFarm
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/geocoder/geocodefarm.py", line 10, in <module>
    class GeocodeFarm(Base):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/geocoder/geocodefarm.py", line 37, in GeocodeFarm
    key = self._get_api_key(geocodefarm_key, **kwargs)
NameError: name 'self' is not defined
```

This happens simply from the following in my code:

`import geocoder`

Breaking commit:

[https://github.com/DenisCarriere/geocoder/commit/ac7e2afa1447648f64c4940a46ec431dbf6b3bfa](https://github.com/DenisCarriere/geocoder/commit/ac7e2afa1447648f64c4940a46ec431dbf6b3bfa)

Breaking diff in `geocoder/geocodefarm.py`:

```
     provider = 'geocodefarm'
     method = 'geocode'

+    key = self._get_api_key(geocodefarm_key, **kwargs)
+
     def __init__(self, location, **kwargs):
         self.url = 'https://www.geocode.farm/v3/json/forward/'
-
-        key = kwargs.get('key', geocodefarm_key)
-
         self.params = {
             'addr': location,
             'key': key if key else None,
```

The variable `self` is not defined in the new code (line 37).  I suspect the new line is supposed to go in place of the removed line (i.e. inside the `__init__` function - the same way as was done in `geocoder/geocodefarm_reverse.py`.

items.title: ArcGIS Does Not Use Proxy
items.body:
Hi!

I passed a bogus proxy to a few providers and noticed that ArcGIS does not throw an exception as expected.  Any thoughts?

``` python
import geocoder
# Throws an exception
g = geocoder.google('New York City', proxies={'https':'Hello!'})
# Does not throw an exception
a = geocoder.arcgis('New York City', proxies={'https':'Hello!'})
```

items.title: Google RateLimit Broken
items.body: Rate limiting seems to be broken when using provider Google since I'm getting a g.status of OVER_QUERY_LIMIT.  Might be related to the recent https://github.com/DenisCarriere/geocoder/commit/4c965abc38f3b8686ae98b53bf49028275605b20 commit.  Looks like the Google for Work limits got uncommented, possibly overwriting the previous @ratelim.greedy() settings?

items.title: Google - Encoded before hashing
items.body:
@Chartres The Google provider is giving me issues with Python3. It says the objects need to be encoded before hashing.

The Google example seems to work using Python2, can you give it a shot?

https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/directions/get-api-key#client-id

> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
>   File "/home/denis/Github/geocoder/geocoder/api.py", line 159, in google
>     return get(location, provider='google', **kwargs)
>   File "/home/denis/Github/geocoder/geocoder/api.py", line 126, in get
>     return options[provider][method](location, **kwargs)
>   File "/home/denis/Github/geocoder/geocoder/google.py", line 54, in **init**
>     self._encode_params(**kwargs)
>   File "/home/denis/Github/geocoder/geocoder/google.py", line 63, in _encode_params
>     self.params.append(self._sign_url(self.url, self.params, self.client_secret))
>   File "/home/denis/Github/geocoder/geocoder/google.py", line 105, in _sign_url
>     signature = hmac.new(decoded_key, url_to_sign, hashlib.sha1)
>   File "/home/denis/Github/geocoder/env/lib/python3.4/hmac.py", line 144, in new
>     return HMAC(key, msg, digestmod)
>   File "/home/denis/Github/geocoder/env/lib/python3.4/hmac.py", line 84, in __init__
>     self.update(msg)
>   File "/home/denis/Github/geocoder/env/lib/python3.4/hmac.py", line 93, in update
>     self.inner.update(msg)
> TypeError: Unicode-objects must be encoded before hashing

Also this  error **expected bytes, but got 'str'**:

> self = <hmac.HMAC object at 0x7fb24e496350>
> msg = '/maps/api/geocode/json?address=%E6%9D%B1%E4%BA%AC&client=gme-anheuserbuschinbev'
>     def update(self, msg):
>         """Update this hashing object with the string msg.
>             """
>         if not isinstance(msg, bytes):
>           raise TypeError("expected bytes, but got %r" % type(msg).**name**)
> E           TypeError: expected bytes, but got 'str'

items.title: geocoder.base.Base should not call sys.exit()
items.body:
The decision on how to handle a KeyboardInterrupt exception should be left up to the application, not a module.  [geocoder.base.Base._connect()](https://github.com/DenisCarriere/geocoder/blob/master/geocoder/base.py) currently does this:

``` python
        except KeyboardInterrupt:
            sys.exit()
```

Which takes the decision on how to handle a KeyboardInterrupt away from the application making use of `geocoder.*`.

Filter query by Country for each provider

items.title: Geocoder and Google
items.body: Anyone aware of changes (presumably on Google's side) since Mon Jan 4 which are now breaking the geocoder.google() method in Geocoder?

items.title: bbox to GeoJSON spec
items.body:
Accessing the JSON & GeoJSON attributes will be different

``` python
>>> g = geocoder.google("Ottawa")
>>> g.bbox
{"northeast": [45.53453, -75.2465979], "southwest": [44.962733, -76.3539158]}
>>> g.geojson['bbox']
[-76.3539158, 44.962733, -75.2465979, 45.53453]
>>> g.southwest
[44.962733, -76.3539158]
```

items.title: Provide an easy way how to pass additional aruments
items.body:
Hi Denis!

first of all, thank you for the great work you've done so far.

My problem is that I'd like to use your library for geocoding from geocoder.ca (`Geolytica`) but I didn't find a way how to pass [`auth` parameter](http://geocoder.ca/?premium_api=1) to their API.

Not sure if it is possible to provide additional parameters in general or if it is needed to adjust `Geolytica` driver only.

items.title: UTF-8 Encoding Issue with Python27
items.body:
Hi, I noticed an issue with i18n and the Google geocoder:

For example, 東京 (Tokyo) or  Québec works fine in the Google Rest API
https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/geocode/json?address=東京

However, it fails with:

> > > geocoder.google("東京").json
> > > Traceback (most recent call last):
> > >   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
> > >   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/geocoder-1.6.4-py2.7.egg/geocoder/api.py", line 140, in google
> > >     return get(location, provider='google', *_kwargs)
> > >   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/geocoder-1.6.4-py2.7.egg/geocoder/api.py", line 107, in get
> > >     return options[provider][method](location, *_kwargs)
> > >   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/geocoder-1.6.4-py2.7.egg/geocoder/google.py", line 49, in **init**
> > >     self._encode_params()
> > >   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/geocoder-1.6.4-py2.7.egg/geocoder/google.py", line 56, in _encode_params
> > >     self.params = sorted([(k.encode('utf8'), v.encode('utf8')) for (k, v) in self.params.items() if v])
> > > UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe6 in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)

If I comment out "self.params = sorted([(k.encode('utf8'), v.encode('utf8')) for (k, v) in self.params.items() if v])" of google.py, it works correctly. 

I'm not sure what the line is potentially fixing? Should it just be removed?

items.title: OpenLS API support
items.body:
Hi, the OGC descripes in [Open Location Service 1.2](http://www.opengeospatial.org/standards/ols) - Location Utility Service also an general API for (reverse)geocoding. There are some servers which already implement this standard:
- [OpenRouteService](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/OpenRouteService)
- ArcGIS server (using [this connector](https://github.com/mhogeweg/OpenLS))

You might want to try the [OSM OpenLS Route Service - Testclient](http://openls.geog.uni-heidelberg.de/testing2015/geocoding&help).
This might reduce the workload to add new geocoders if they follow this standard protocol.

items.title: Autocomplete Geocoders
items.body:
Hi, some geocoders support an text autocomplete while a user enters e.g. an address. For example [photon](http://photon.komoot.de/) which is an extended nominatim.

It would be nice if this feature could be used with this lib. Maybe an additional call, or extending the current methods.
Attention: Most geocoder services don't allow  an emulation of this features by permanent polling their API endpoints (e.g. [OSM Nominatim](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Nominatim_usage_policy))

items.title: Baidu Geocoder returns BD-09 geographic coordinate
items.body:
The current Baidu provider[1] returned BD-09[2] coordinate (which encrypted GCJ-02 aka Mars Coordinates)[3], so it only works with Baidu Maps.

It would be nice to address it in the document[1]. Or even better if we put a translator in the module to convert it back to WGS-84 datums as the other geocoder provider.

[1] Baidu — geocoder 1.6.4 documentation http://python-geocoder.org/providers/Baidu.html
[2] Baidu Maps https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baidu_Maps
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Restrictions_on_geographic_data_in_China#BD-09
- 火星坐标系统_百度百科 http://baike.baidu.com/view/3163334.htm

items.title: Add ArcGIS Reverse geocoding
items.body: https://developers.arcgis.com/rest/geocode/api-reference/geocoding-reverse-geocode.htm

items.title: Catching Unhandled Exception
items.body: I found the issue.  The code is capturing all exceptions and reporting them as URL Connection issues.  I commented that out and found that Python was unable to load the SSL module... I was able to correct that.  You might want to capture the message of the exception or report it as "Unhandled Exception" instead of reporting it as a connection issue when that isn't always the issue.

items.title: Clean up documentation Convert all docs to RST
items.body: Markdown isn't cutting it anymore, can't create clean eBooks and PyPi isn't very compatible with Markdown.

items.title: URL Connection error
items.body:
Hi,

I'm trying to use geocoder but I always get an error.  I get a status of "ERROR - URL Connection". I'm running this in Google App Engine.

No matter whether I try Yahoo, OSM or Google I get the same error.

```
    g = geocoder.google("41.1474794 -8.55558", key="ABC-MyKey-XYZ", method="reverse")
    logging.info("ok: " + str(g.ok))
    logging.info("status: " + str(g.status))
```

Any help would be appreciated!

items.title: GeoJSON default output
items.body:
The STDOUT does not work well with JSON output.

Basic GeoJSON output should look like so:

``` bash
$ geocode "Ottawa, ON" >> ottawa.json
```

items.body:
Hi there,
Can we include 'postal_town' as a fallback value for city/city_long, when 'locality' is not returned from Google? For example, 'Ullared' is not a 'locality' but a 'postal_town'. See below:
![2015-07-01 15_05_21-ipython py 2 7](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4778303/8455360/54d2e42a-2004-11e5-993f-7b386e2862c7.png)

items.title: Errors shall throw exceptions instead of sys.exit()
items.body:
Try running 
`geocoder.timezone("463a Hong Bang, P14, Q5")`

This throws an error, which results in program's stop. It is impossible to catch it via try/except, because there is no exception - the code simply does `sys.exit()`. E.g. https://github.com/DenisCarriere/geocoder/blob/master/geocoder/location.py#L98

It is a deal-breaker when processing long list of locations...

Could you please change all errors to throwing exceptions instead of exiting?

items.title: Here geocoder returns "Permission Error"
items.body: The [free HERE Geocoder plan seems to be gone](https://developer.here.com/get-started#/10134037). All geocoding requests return a Permission Error, unless you have a paid license (probably).
